abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Izmir Water Supply and
            Sewerage Project for Turkey were as follows: outcomes were
            highly unsatisfactory, Bank performance in project
            preparation was highly deficient, Bank performance in
            project appraisal was highly deficient, Bank performance in
            project supervision was partially satisfactory, Borrower
            performance in project preparation was deficient, Borrower
            performance in implementation was deficient, and Borrower
            performance in covenant compliance was deficient. Some
            lessons learned included: it is highly risky to attempt to
            compensate for past under investment and neglect of water
            and sewerage systems by undertaking overly ambitious
            investment programs. Choices have to be made to implement
            gradual improvements which adequately take into account the
            prevailing institutional and financial constraints. Emphasis
            should be put on actions and investments required for using
            existing infrastructure in a more efficient manner,
            particularly in cases where there is evidence that poor
            service is due to deficiencies in system operation and
            maintenance practices. Additions to installed capacity to
            meet future demands should not be undertaken as a substitute
            for improving operation and maintenance, and should not put
            an excessive burden on the borrower's implementation
            and financial capacity.
